ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS



    The following Questions Nos. 1, 2 and 3 stood in the name of Haji Sha'ari Bin Tadin -

HOUSING BOARD FLATS USE OF VOID DECKS


    1. To ask the Minister for National Development and Communications if he will ask the Housing and Development Board to consider reducing by half the present high rental for the use of void decks charged to residents of purchased blocks and exempting Residents' Block Committees from payment of the rental when decks are used for residents' functions.

Column: 458



    Mr Speaker: Haji Sha'ari.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Question No. 1, Sir.

    The Senior Minister of State for National Development (Dr Tan Eng Liang) (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the present rental of $50 per day for the use of void decks is applicable to all residents in the housing estates and not just to those in purchased blocks.

    This rental is levied by the Board to cover the costs of three cleaners, a supervising mandore to clean up the space after its use, inspectors to check the condition of the space before and after its use, and the need

Column: 459

for periodic repairs and colour washings of the areas as a result of continuous intensive use of the space. It is also to cover the electricity supply and, in the case of newer blocks. water supply from the standpipes.

    The rental of $50 is reasonable as compared to the rentals charged by other organisations like St. John's Ambulance. People's Association and Fraser and Neave for the use of social function halls which normally range between $100 and $160 per day, between stipulated hours for each occasion

    For these reasons, it is not recommended that the present rental of $50 for the use of void decks be reduced.

    The rate must also be applied uniformly to residents as well as non-governmental associations including the Residents' Block Committees, as any departure from this practice would give rise to complaints of unequal treatment and favouritism

CONSTRUCTION OF BUS SHELTERS AT NEW UPPER CHANGI ROAD AND BEDOK WALK


    2. To ask the Minister for National Development and Communications whether and when bus shelters will be constructed in front of Block 29, New Upper Changi Road and Block 11, Bedok Walk

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Question No 2, Sir

Column: 459

POST OFFICE IN BEDOK NEW TOWN
(NEIGHBOURHOOD I)


    3. To ask the Minister for National Development and Communications if it is planned to set up a post office in Neighbourhood I of Bedok New Town and when it is expected to be ready

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Question No 3. Sir.

Column: 460



    The Senior Minister of State for Communications (Mr Ong Teng Cheong) (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no plan to set up a post office in Neighbourhood I of Bedok New Town. However, a post office will be established in the Bedok Town Centre which is adjacent to Neighbourhood I. This post office will serve the whole of Bedok New Town and will be ready in early 1978. In the meantime, there is a mobile post office providing temporary services from 9.00 am. to 12.30 p.m., Mondays to Saturdays, at the car park at Bedok Plain in Neighbourhood I.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): Mr Speaker, Sir, a supplementary question. Judging by the number of questions raised by a number of hon Members these two days, it would seem to me that there is no comprehensive planning of the provision of basic facilities and amenities in the new housing estates. Would the hon. Minister of State please inform the House as to what sort of coordination exists between the Housing and Development Board and all the other Ministries?

    Dr Tan Eng Liang: Mr Speaker, Sir, in my reply to some of the observations made by hon. Members, in particular the arrangements between the Singapore Bus Service and the Housing and Development Board, I indicated that in the planning of new estates the HDB does consult the bus authority. But for more detailed planning, especially of providing bus services to the new estates, a lot depends on when the residents have moved into a particular area. As to exactly where the bus routes are going to be, it will depend on the actual situation of resident-occupancy when it is nearer the period of completion. I have also informed Members of this House that the HDB and the SBS have a planning committee which is looking into this.

    As to the general planning of HDB estates. I can assure Members here that in the overall planning of a new estate. for example, the Bedok New Town. either Neighbourhood I or II. all the necessary main infrastructure is

Column: 461

planned well in advance, For instance, the necessary requirements for sewerage, social amenities, public utilities and major roads, are all planned ahead of time. But the more detailed requirements within the Neighbourhood, such as in Bedok New Town Neighbourhood II. will have to be done nearer the period of completion.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: In this case. Mr Speaker, Sir, would not the Ministry of National Development look into the question of providing other social services, such as community centres, post office, and related services which cater to the needs of the residents more than just bus services only?

    Dr Tan Eng Liang: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have said that the provision of bus services will be included in the more detailed arrangements between the HDB and the SBS when the period of residential occupation is nearer to full completion. But I do assure Members that as far as overall planning of a particular estate is concerned; roads, post office. including a library, are standing instruction for HDB architects to incorporate them in all new estates.

    With regard to the Member's suggestion for the provision of community centres, there is a thinking whether community centres should be incorporated as a standard requirement in all HOB estates. I think that is left to be discussed.

2.37 p.m.

    The Senior Minister of State for Communications (Mr Ong Teng Cheong): Mr Speaker, Sir, before I deal with the various points raised by hon. Members in this House, let me recall the lament of the British Prime Minister which was referred to in the President's Address and which our own Prime Minister reiterated yesterday. The British Prime Minister was said to have lamented that the most hateful slogan he has ever heard was made at the protest march of Marxist infiltrators of his Labour Party: "What do we want? Everything. When do we want it? Now!" I cannot agree with him more, Sir, that this is lamentable not only because the demand was unreasonable and impossible to meet but also because this is happening to a once-great nation.

    This reminds me of the analogical example of the sniffers of roses once quoted by our hon. Minister for Foreign Affairs. The sniffer of roses, upon discovering that a rose smells better than a cabbage or onion, concludes that it will make better soup. He therefore demands the soup while sniffing at the roses. On the other hand, the soup maker or the so-called "establishment" unfortunately has to get down to the more exacting job of producing the soup which normally falls short of expectation of the rose sniffers. Sometimes they may not even meet the taste of every Member in this House. Sir, I am not for a moment suggesting that the hon. Members on the other side of this House or on this side of the House are sniffers of roses. I have not the slightest intention of implying so. Sir. I happen to know that they are no roses, notwithstanding the fact that 100 flowers are allowed to blossom in this House.

    An hon. Member: And to be chopped off!

    Mr Ong Teng Cheong: I was only trying to illustrate how difficult it is sometimes for reasons to prevail when faced with such an impatient and recalcitrant lot who demands nothing less but the out-of-this-world fantasy of "everything now!" Well, Rome was not built in one day. Sir. No great nation was ever built in one day. Whatever brilliant plan for

Column: 463

development we may have, it must be accompanied by a practical programme of implementation. The critical path must be clearly defined and the order of priority put right. Confucius, in his opening chapter of The Great Learning said:

    `Every entity has its origin and termination, Every event has its beginning and ending. To know the sequence thereof and the order of priority, is to be near Tao (the way).'

    For the benefit of my learned colleagues on the other side of the House, especially the Member for Katong. it goes like this in Chinese: Wu you ben mo, shi you shi zhong, zhi suo xian hou, ze jin dao yi.

    An hon. Member: I do not understand this!

    Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Well, those hon. Members who do not understand this are recommended to read the book. It is in the opening chapter.

    With this note, Sir, I shall now reply to the various points raised by the hon. Members. First of all, the hon. Members for Telok Blangah and Punggol are unhappy about the inadequate bus service in new towns and new housing estates. They suspected that this was due to a lack of liaison and coordination between the Singapore Bus Service and the Housing and Development Board. But as my colleague -

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, on a point of clarification if the hon. Minister of State will give way.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Ong, are you prepared to give way?

    Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Yes [and resumed his seat].

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, I did not say that the residents are unhappy. What I said was that there should be overall planning so as to provide bus services to the residents of the new towns, because public transportation is a natural expectation of the residents. Surely, when the residents move in, bus services must naturally follow.

Column: 464



    Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Sir, the answer to the query is: there actually is. The SBS is, in fact, liaising very closely with the HDB on this matter. When a new town is opened up and people begin moving in, bus services are provided at the same time, The level of services, that is. the frequency and types of services, increases as more and more people move in. Good examples are Ang Mo Kio and Bedok New Town. Telok Blangah New Town and other new estates, including industrial estates, will have more and more services as they fill up. I have no doubt that in view of what I said earlier, quoting Confucius. the hon. Members would appreciate that it is not always possible or practicable to provide everything all at the same time.

    Each month, SBS adds 10 to 20 new buses to its fleet. Therefore, the fleet is increasing, but these new buses have to be allocated to the various new towns and new estates. In other words, each new town or estate will have its fair share of bus services,

    With regard to the request for improvement of the transport services in the rural areas, made by the Members for Bukit Panjang and for Punggol. I would like to assure them that the SBS, in its efforts to upgrade its island-wide services will not overlook the requirements of the rural areas,

    The Member for Paya Lebar has suggested that canteens and toilets for bus employees should be set up at bus terminals. The SBS management is conscious of the need to provide proper facilities because they lead to an increase of moral and higher efficiency of the staff. Wherever practicable, toilets have been built and canteens provided even to the extent of building "bus canteens". that is, converting old bus bodies into canteens as a temporary measure. Improvements, unfortunately have not been as rapid as the management would want to see, for a number of reasons, among which are the unavailability of land to build these facilities, uncertainty over long-term status of the land, the temporary nature of some locations and so on. Where the long-term status of the terminal is determined and where land is available, proper terminal facilities have been developed.

Column: 465



    At the Paya Lebar International Airport, for example, a new terminal has been built and another one would soon be completed at Jurong, The SBS is now making a concerted effort to upgrade all sub-standard terminals. Since September last year. Sir, it has embarked on a terminal improvement programme. Various Government authorities, such as the Registry of Vehicles, the Public Works Department and the Housing and Development Board, are cooperating to improve and, where possible. to build proper terminals.

    Sir, as with all limited resources, improvements cost money and, therefore, would have to be carried Out in stages over the next three to five years.

    The Member for Bukit Ho Swee has suggested that more women should be employed by the SBS and trained to be bus drivers and conductors because they are not as impatient and rude as men. I agree with his observation. With the recruitment of female bus conductors, the number of complaints of rudeness from commuters has dropped and the bus conductors are now more courteous in their work. The policy of the SBS with regard to recruitment since August 1974 has been to engage women to work as bus conductors. Equal encouragement has also been given to the recruitment of women as bus drivers. As a result of this policy almost one-third of the bus conductors in the SBS now are women. The recruitment of women as bus drivers has been, unfortunately, less successful. The staffing position of bus crew in the Company as at 31st January this year is as follows. There is a total of 3,592 bus conductors and 3,737 bus drivers, Of these, 1,121 bus conductors and 34 bus drivers are women. Although the SBS has tried every means to attract women to join the Company as bus conductors, the supply is tapering off, with the result that men have to be employed again as bus conductors so as to obtain a sufficient number of conductors to pair off with the bus drivers to meet the immediate shortage. In spite of this move, the SBS is

Column: 466

still making every effort to encourage women to be employed as bus drivers and conductors,

    I would now refer to the point raised by the Member for Moulmein on whether or not the objective of the Area Licensing Scheme (ALS) would still be served by terminating the hours of restriction at 9.45 a.m. instead of 10.15 a.m. Hon. Members will recall that when the ALS was introduced in June 1975 the hours of restriction were from 7.30 a.m. to 9.30 a.m. While the number of motor vehicles entering the Central Business District (CBD) was substantially reduced during those hours of restriction, traffic increased considerably after 9.30 a.m. giving rise to severe traffic congestion along the major roads on the fringe of the CBD between 9.30 a.m. and 10.00 a.m. From August 1975 the hours of restriction were extended to 10.15 a.m. This had effectively eliminated traffic congestion between 9.30 a.m. and 10.15 a.m. There was still, however, an upsurge in the volume of traffic entering the CBD between 10.15 a.m. and 10.45 a.m., but the congestion was of a reduced scale and of short duration. Observations of traffic conditions up to the end of last year indicate that there has been a gradual upward creep in the post-10.15 a.m. traffic volume in recent months. Therefore, shortening of the restricted hours now would certainly result in a further deterioration of traffic conditions and the need again for further restraint. It would be prudent, therefore, to retain the present hours of restraint, that is, from 7.30 a.m. to 10.15 a.m.

    The Member for Telok Blangah spoke on the lighterage trade and suggested that the breakwater at Pasir Panjang be extended to make the water there safer for lighters to operate. The PSA wants the lighterage trade to continue as it supplements the normal cargo traffic. Because of this the PSA is developing Pasir Panjang with a lighterage cargo handling and mooring area. Before completion of the breakwater, the waters at Pasir Panjang were quite choppy and not too conducive for the handling of cargo to and

Column: 467

from lighters. Since September last year when the two arms of the breakwater costing almost $6 million were completed, lighters could safely moor and operate at Pasir Panjang. The PSA is in contact with the Singapore Lighter Owner's Association on this and other matters concerning lighterage. and they are presently satisfied with the water conditions at Pasir Panjang. In fact, since November last year. with the introduction of the reduced tariff and the completion of the breakwater at Pasir Panjang. there has been a sharp increase in the lighterage cargo from an average of 21,269 tonnes per month from January to October last year to an average of 67,483 tonnes per month from November last year to January this year. To further promote the lighterage trade and to allow for a lighterage operation at both the Eastern and Western Anchorages, the PSA is also considering providing a lighter mooring area for about 60 lighters alongside the HDB reclaimed land at Telok Aver Basin.

    The Member for Telok Blangah also spoke on behalf of those who were unsuccessful in their application for PSA passes for entry into the PSA. The Member for Telok Blangah may wish to take note of this. The PSA issues more than 102,000 passes to port users valid as at end of last year. In a representative survey carried out last year, out of a total number of 13,507 applications for PSA passes, 12,995 were approved outright. Upon appeal, an additional 187 were granted PSA passes.

    Sir, it can be seen that there is actually only a very small fraction of about 2.4% of the total applications not given passes to enter the PSA port area. The PSA has the responsibility to ensure that its premises are kept reasonably safe, and that entry is confined to those who have legitimate business with the port. The port users must generally be of acceptable character and who would not cause a nuisance to the port in one way or another The reputation of the PSA as a generally pilferage-free port with good security has to be safeguarded and, as such, the Authority cannot approve all applications without proper screening.

Column: 468



    Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi (Kampong Kembangan): Mr Speaker, Sir, on a point of clarification. If I recall correctly, the point raised was why did the PSA disapprove applications for passes or withdraw the passes issued merely on the basis of minor criminal records committed a few years ago.

    Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I have mentioned earlier. about 187 cases were granted after appeal. I have also mentioned earlier, the importance of protecting the image of the PSA as a pilferage-free port. If we want to develop Singapore as a transhipment centre, as the Member for Marine Parade would like it to be. then we have to maintain that image. Normally when goods or items are stolen from the warehouse, they would not be discovered until months later when the cargoes reach their destination overseas. So there is a need to screen all applications. But each application upon appeal would be given the opportunity of a further consideration, and the applicants would be either granted a pass or otherwise depending on the merits of the application.

    Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi: Mr Speaker, Sir, on a further point of clarification. Sir, I do not in any way suggest that the PSA should not screen applicants for PSA passes. In fact, I had the happy occasion of getting a very clear reply from the PSA stating the reasons why applications were rejected. The point is why must the PSA disapprove, first, on the strength of petty crimes committed many years ago and only awaits for the person to appeal. I had such cases in my constituency and, pending appeal, these people are jobless. May I repeat, Mr Speaker, Sir, and also to the Minister, that I do not in any way suggest that the PSA should be lax in its screening. In fact, it should screen the applications in order to maintain its reputation.

    Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not know whether the Member wants me to reply to his point. But if he has any problems here, I would suggest that he refers them to me I cannot give him a definite reply unless these specific cases are investigated.

Column: 469



    The hon. Member for Marine Parade suggested that we should strive to be a world transhipment centre and not just rest on our laurels as a regional warehousing and transhipment centre. This is exactly what we are striving to be. It is only due to modesty that we use the term "regional transhipment centre" instead of "world transhipment centre" in the Addendum.

    The Port of Singapore Authority is presently offering a number of incentives to encourage cargo transhipment at Singapore. Incentives are in the form of lower charges for stevedorage and wharf handling for conventional cargo. For containerised cargo the charge for stevedorage is also reduced by half from $200 to $100 per 20-foot container. In addition, for both conventional and containerised cargo, free storage up to 28 days is given as against the normal 72 hours free storage given for local cargo. Cargo from conventional vessels to be transhipped on to container lines are given a tariff incentive of $4 per tonne rebate. These incentives have assisted Singapore's development as a regional transhipment centre. To encourage further development of Singapore as an intercontinental transhipment centre, particularly for cargo from Europe, Mediterranean and Middle East to Australia and New Zealand, the PSA is developing the inland container depot which will provide cheaper storage for containers both loaded and empty. The ample space at the inland depot would also allow for cargo consolidation and repacking which are sometimes necessary before transhipment. If necessary, further incentives in the form of tariff or other incentives will be considered.

    The hon. Member for Alexandra has suggested that air cargo charter services be allowed to operate out of Singapore offering rates lower than regular scheduled airlines so as to allow our export industries to transport their goods to the markets at lower cost. The hon. Member is probably aware that freight rates for air cargo charters are a matter of agreement between airline operators and charterers or shippers. This agreed rate is

Column: 470

determined by market forces and is usually different from the published rate for scheduled airlines. One of the main aims of Government is to develop Singapore as an air cargo distribution and storage centre. And in pursuing this objective. Sir, the operation of both scheduled and non-scheduled airlines, including air cargo charter services, will be encouraged. We will strive to create an atmosphere conducive to efficient airline operation by streamlining administrative procedure, reducing bureaucratic redtape and providing the necessary infrastructure at competitive prices.

3.04 p.m.

    The Minister for Home Affairs and Education (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, several points have been raised by hon. Members concerning the Ministry of Home Affairs. I will now deal with them subject by subject.

    First, on internal security. Sir, I am gratified to note that among the subjects under Home Affairs, internal security was the subject which received the most attention. All those who spoke on it agreed that the communists are and will remain the main threat to Singapore's internal security. Some Members rightly stressed the need for vigilance not only on the part of the authorities but also amongst our people. This is crucial because the communists will use every means at their disposal to subvert individuals and organisations and use them to advance their cause.

    To achieve their objectives they will not hesitate to employ every form of deceit and treachery, use violence and commit any crime including murder. They believe in the philosophy that the end justifies the means. They operate clandestinely through their underground network. When they have ensnared sufficient numbers of open front leaders in mass organisations to act as their proxies above ground, then they would launch what is known as a Communist United Front offensive and create strikes. riots and instability as in the 1950s and early 1960s in Singapore.

Column: 471



    The Ministry of Home Affairs has taken great pains to publicise and expose their machinations after every major security operation. It is hoped that this would educate our public and keep them constantly on their guard against attempts at subversion by the communists.

    The hon. Member for Khe Bong managed to draw laughter in this House when he spoke on internal security. However. there are one or two points that he raised which are serious and need to be replied to. He had suggested that internal security measures taken are still inadequate and not thorough enough. He referred to G. Raman and asked why was it that he had not been arrested earlier since he was a communist some time ago.

    The answer is that G. Raman did come to our security notice quite some time ago. But it is not necessarily the best strategy of combating communist subversion by making an immediate arrest once a single communist has been identified. We should first try to identify his associates so that they also can be taken in. On this, we have to exercise great care and thoroughness in our investigations to ensure that the wrong persons are not detained. Otherwise our action will be counterproductive. I do not think I should go further than this in my explanation lest we unwittingly give away information of our strategy to our enemy. What I would like to emphasise here is that the real test of the effectiveness of our Internal Security Department is not whether communists and other subversive groups continue to exist but rather whether they are identified and dealt with before they can do any real harm. On this, Sir, the records of ISO's achievements not only in the present G Raman's case but also in smashing other underground communist groups and network speak for themselves.

    The hon. Member for Khe Bong has also suggested that information be gathered from Government departments. I do not know exactly what he has in mind. But I would like to assure him that no effort has been and will be spared to gather information of security

Column: 472

interest not only from Government departments, schools, but also elsewhere. The ISD will continue to take periodic security action to pre-empt the communists underground and keep them on the run.

    The hon. Member for Leng Kee, while stating that hardcore communists should be severely dealt with, has suggested that students and youths who had been misled into supporting the communists should be given a chance to correct themselves. In answer, may I just refer to what I said in a TV interview in the programme entitled "Year-End Roundup 1976". And I quote:

    'in the security operations, the powers of detention under the internal Security Act were used discriminately. Only the hardcore and those who refuse to recant their communist involvement were issued with Orders of Detention.

    The students who were released went back to their studies. Those who had superficial involvements were called up together with their parents and warned of the dangers of associations with communist subversives.'

However, this programme was broadcast during the midst of the 1976 General Elections, I am sure the Member for Leng Kee was busy campaigning at that time and must have missed the programme.

    Turning to road safety I must confess that I am somewhat disappointed that only a few Members had any comments or suggestions. However, the Member for Kallang had raised some points which need to be answered. He criticised the proposal to change the law to put the onus on the driver of a larger vehicle to prove that he was not in the wrong in any collision between a larger and a smaller vehicle. He said that it was an example of "legislative overkill". He contended that the drivers of smaller vehicles like motorcyclists and scooterists could be equally at fault. He called for the problem to be tackled by other measures such as education. stricter enforcement. more severe punishment for those found guilty.

    In answer, let me first put this proposal for change in the law in its proper perspective. It is not an isolated proposal but it is part of a series of new and more vigorous measures which included greater efforts in educating road users in the highway code. culminating

Column: 473

in a nationwide "Road Safety For You" Campaign in June 1977. This will be followed with vigorous and stricter enforcement to cut down the carnage that is going on on our roads.
